message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Signaling Theory: State of the Theory and Its Future
Paper Abstract: Signaling theory is about decision-making and communication. It describes scenarios where signalers send observable signals that carry credible information about unobservable qualities. When decision-makers have incomplete or imperfect information, signals can help them make better decisions. The power of a signal, though, lies in its cost, with the best signals being highly costly for low-quality signalers and less costly for high-quality signalers. Given the centrality of these ideas in the organizational sciences, we examine management studies that use signaling theory to help explain phenomena that occur within and among organizations. Our review draws attention to how signaling theorists have introduced important complexities to the signaling process, uncovered theoretical boundary conditions of signaling, described new actors within signaling systems, and demonstrated novel ways to apply signaling theory to understand behavior in an array of research contexts involving a wide range of organizational stakeholders. We also offer ideas about how scholars can account for costs when they apply the theory, extend the theory in more organizational settings, and create abstract extensions of the theory’s major concepts. Our intent is to provide researchers with a panoramic perspective on the state of signaling theory and inspire further development so that we can collectively advance signaling theory as much in the next decade as it has advanced in the last.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Organizational Behavior"

I've completed the web search for "Organizational behavior" and found comprehensive information about this field. Here are the key findings:

### Definition
Organizational behavior is the "study of human behavior in organizational settings, the interface between human behavior and the organization, and the organization itself".

### Focus Areas
Topics examined include motivation, leadership behavior, task performance, problem solving and decision making, group functioning, and other classes of behavior relevant to organizational effectiveness.

### Research Methods
A variety of methods are used in organizational behavior, with quantitative research allowing organizational behavior to be studied and compared through numerical data, and a key advantage being that efficient examinations of large groups can be studied at lower costs and in less time.

### Historical Development
The best known theories today originate from Henri Fayol, Chester Barnard, and Mary Parker Follet, and each of their theories independently shared a focus on human behavior and motivation.

### Important Subdisciplines
Organizational behavior management (OBM) is a subdiscipline of applied behavior analysis (ABA), which is the application of behavior analytic principles and contingency management techniques to change behavior in organizational settings.

### Key Research Journals
Several peer-reviewed journals are dedicated to publishing organizational behavior research, including the Journal of Organizational Behavior, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, and the Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Search Results for "Organizational Behavior"

I've completed the web search for "Organizational behavior" and found comprehensive information about this field. Here are the key findings:

### Definition
Organizational behavior is the "study of human behavior in organizational settings, the interface between human behavior and the organization, and the organization itself".

### Focus Areas
Topics examined include motivation, leadership behavior, task performance, problem solving and decision making, group functioning, and other classes of behavior relevant to organizational effectiveness.

### Research Methods
A variety of methods are used in organizational behavior, with quantitative research allowing organizational behavior to be studied and compared through numerical data, and a key advantage being that efficient examinations of large groups can be studied at lower costs and in less time.

### Historical Development
The best known theories today originate from Henri Fayol, Chester Barnard, and Mary Parker Follet, and each of their theories independently shared a focus on human behavior and motivation.

### Important Subdisciplines
Organizational behavior management (OBM) is a subdiscipline of applied behavior analysis (ABA), which is the application of behavior analytic principles and contingency management techniques to change behavior in organizational settings.

### Key Research Journals
Several peer-reviewed journals are dedicated to publishing organizational behavior research, including the Journal of Organizational Behavior, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, and the Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior.

Web search results for query: "Signaling Theory"

Links: [{"title":"Costly signaling theory in evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costly_signaling_theory_in_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Signalling theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_theory"},{"title":"Signalling (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_(economics)"},{"title":"Talk:Signalling theory/GA1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Signalling_theory%2FGA1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signaling_game"},{"title":"Lewis signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_signaling_game"},{"title":"Amotz Zahavi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amotz_Zahavi"},{"title":"Friendship jealousy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendship_jealousy"},{"title":"Dividend policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dividend_Decision"},{"title":"Information asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Signaling Theory:

## Overview

Signaling theory is a body of theoretical work within evolutionary biology examining communication between individuals, both within and across species, that addresses how organisms with conflicting interests are expected to provide honest signals rather than deceive or cheat.

## Key Applications

Signaling theory has multiple applications across different domains:

### Evolutionary Biology
Signals evolve because they modify the behavior of the receiver to benefit the signaller.(no content)Signals may be honest, conveying information which usefully increases the fitness of the receiver, or dishonest.

### Economics
In contract theory, signaling is the idea that one party (the agent) credibly conveys some information about itself to another party (the principal).(no content)Signaling theory was more fully developed by Michael Spence, specifically in the context of observed knowledge gaps between organisations and prospective employees.(no content)In Spence's job-market signaling model, (potential) employees send a signal about their ability level to the employer by acquiring education credentials.

### The Handicap Principle
Amotz Zahavi suggested that cheating could be controlled by the handicap principle, where signallers such as male peacocks have "tails" that are genuinely handicaps, being costly to produce.

### Game Theory
In game theory, a signaling game is a type of dynamic Bayesian game where one player takes action, the signal, to convey information to another player.

Web search results for query: "Information asymmetry economics"

Links: [{"title":"Information asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry"},{"title":"Screening (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screening_(economics)"},{"title":"Regulatory economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_economics"},{"title":"Economic transparency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_transparency"},{"title":"Networks in labor economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networks_in_labor_economics"},{"title":"Cyclical asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclical_asymmetry"},{"title":"Signalling (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_(economics)"},{"title":"The Market for Lemons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Market_for_Lemons"},{"title":"Adverse selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adverse_selection"},{"title":"Information economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_economics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about information asymmetry in economics:

## Definition

In contract theory, mechanism design, and economics, an information asymmetry is a situation where one party has more or better information than the other.(no content)Information asymmetry is in contrast to perfect information, which is a key assumption in neo-classical economics.

## Effects on Markets

Information asymmetry creates an imbalance of power in transactions, which can sometimes cause the transactions to be inefficient, causing market failure in the worst case.(no content)Examples of this problem are adverse selection, moral hazard, and monopolies of knowledge.

## Key Problems

**Adverse Selection:** In economics, insurance, and risk management, adverse selection is a market situation where asymmetric information results in a party taking advantage of undisclosed information to benefit more from a contract or trade.

**Moral Hazard:** Adverse selection regards behavior before a contract takes place whereas moral hazard describes a party's action after the contract had already been made.

## Notable Research

In 1996, a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics was awarded to James A. Mirrlees and William Vickrey for their "fundamental contributions to the economic theory of incentives under asymmetric information". In 2001, George Akerlof, Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz won the Nobel Prize for their "analyses of markets with asymmetric information".

## Classic Example: The Market for Lemons

George Akerlof's paper The Market for Lemons introduced a model to help explain a variety of market outcomes when quality is uncertain.(no content)Akerlof examines how the quality of goods traded in a market can degrade in the presence of information asymmetry between buyers and sellers, which ultimately leaves goods that are found to be defective after purchase in the market.

Links: [{"title":"Organizational behavior management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior_management"},{"title":"Organizational behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior"},{"title":"Organizational behavior and human resources - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior_and_human_resources"},{"title":"Outline of organizational theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_organizational_theory"},{"title":"Vijay Pereira - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijay_Pereira"},{"title":"Weatherhead School of Management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Business_as_an_Agent_of_World_Benefit"},{"title":"Contingency theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingency_theory"},{"title":"History of contingency theories of leadership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_contingency_theories_of_leadership"},{"title":"Chris Argyris - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Argyris"},{"title":"Complexity theory and organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity_theory_and_organizations"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Organizational Behavior Management:

## Definition and Overview

Organizational behavior management (OBM) is a subdiscipline of applied behavior analysis (ABA), which is the application of behavior analytic principles and contingency management techniques to change behavior in organizational settings.

## Core Principles and Applications

OBM seeks to analyze and employ antecedent (influencing actions before an action occurs) and consequence (what happens as a result of someone's actions) interventions which influence behaviors linked to the mission and key objectives of the organization and its workers.(no content)Such interventions have proven effective through research in improving common organizational areas including employee productivity, delivery of feedback, safety, and overall morale of said organization.

## Historical Development

Founded in 1977, the Journal of Organizational Behavior Management (JOBM) served as a milestone in the field of Organizational Behavior Management.(no content)Areas addressed throughout JOBM include performance measurement, performance level interventions, goal setting, feedback, incentive programs, and evidence-based management.

## Specialty Areas

Organizational Behavior Management (OBM) has expanded, establishing specialty areas such as performance management, systems analysis, and behavior-based safety, which are now widely recognised.(no content)Performance Management (PM) is the implementation of behavioral principles to manage the performance of individual employees or a group of employees, focusing on improving individual and organizational performance.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about organization theory in business:

## Definition

Organizational theory refers to a series of interrelated concepts that involve the sociological study of the structures and operations of formal social organizations.(no content)Organizational theory also seeks to explain how interrelated units of organization either connect or do not connect with each other.

## Key Focus Areas

Organizational theory concerns understanding how groups of individuals behave, which may differ from the behavior of an individual, with the behavior it often focuses on being goal-directed.(no content)Organizational theory covers both intra-organizational and inter-organizational fields of study.

## Major Theories

Theories of organizations include rational system perspective, division of labor, bureaucratic theory, and contingency theory. Some important historical perspectives include:

- **Weber's Bureaucracy**: Weber claimed that bureaucracies are goal-oriented organizations that use their efficiency and rational principles to reach their goals.

- **Neoclassical Perspective**: This approach gave emphasis to "affective and socio-psychological aspects of human behavior in organizations," and suggested that employees have social and psychological needs along with economic needs in order to be motivated to complete their assigned tasks.

- **Contingency Theory**: Contingency theory holds that an organization must try to maximize performance by minimizing the effects of various environmental and internal constraints.

Web search results for query: "Decision-making psychology economics"

Links: [{"title":"Decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_theory"},{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Behavioral economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_economics"},{"title":"Neuroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroeconomics"},{"title":"Bounded rationality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Prospect theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prospect_theory"},{"title":"Rational choice model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_choice_model"},{"title":"Managerial economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Managerial_economics"},{"title":"Decision field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_field_theory"}]

I've completed a web search on decision-making psychology and economics. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Decision theory is a branch of probability, economics, and analytic philosophy that uses expected utility and probability to model how individuals would behave rationally under uncertainty.

## Traditional vs. Behavioral Approaches

Scholars like Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky challenged the assumptions of rational decision-making, with their work in behavioral economics highlighting cognitive biases and heuristics that influence real-world decisions.(no content)In psychology, decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options. In contrast, in economics, it is thought that if humans are rational and free to make their own decisions, then they would behave according to rational choice theory.

## Key Concepts

**Bounded Rationality:** Bounded rationality is the idea that when individuals make decisions, their rationality is limited by the tractability of the decision problem, their cognitive limitations and the time available, and Herbert A. Simon proposed bounded rationality as an alternative basis for the mathematical modeling of decision-making.

**Prospect Theory:** Prospect theory is a theory of behavioral economics, judgment and decision making that was developed by Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky in 1979.

**Heuristics:** Heuristics are procedures for making a decision without working out the consequences of every option, and they decrease the amount of evaluative thinking required for decisions, focusing on some aspects of the decision while ignoring others.

## Neuroeconomics

Neuroeconomics is an interdisciplinary field that seeks to explain human decision-making, the ability to process multiple alternatives and to follow through on a plan of action.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of communication theory:

## Definition and Purpose

Communication theory is a proposed description of communication phenomena, the relationships among them, a storyline describing these relationships, and an argument for these three elements.(no content)Theory can be seen as a way to map the world and make it navigable; communication theory gives us tools to answer empirical, conceptual, or practical communication questions.

## Key Perspectives

Communication theory emphasizes its symbolic and social process aspects as seen from two perspectives—as exchange of information (the transmission perspective), and as work done to connect and thus enable that exchange (the ritual perspective).

## Historical Development

Communication theories have emerged from multiple historical points of origin, including classical traditions of oratory and rhetoric, Enlightenment-era conceptions of society and the mind, and post-World War II efforts to understand propaganda and relationships between media and society.

## Core Elements

One key activity in communication theory is the development of models and concepts used to describe communication. Some of the basic elements studied include the source (information source), sender (transmitter), channel (medium used to transmit the signal), receiver, and destination (the person for whom the message is intended).

## Domains and Epistemologies

Communication theories may fall within distinct domains of interest, including information theory, rhetoric and speech, interpersonal communication, organizational communication, sociocultural communication, political communication, computer-mediated communication, and critical perspectives on media and communication.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Signaling Theory: State of the Theory and Its Future" paper. Here's what was done:

### Paper Classification
**Type: SURVEY** - This is a literature review that examines management studies using signaling theory rather than proposing new methodology.

### Extracted Triples (6 entities)

1. **Signalling theory** (concept) - The foundational theoretical framework examined across organizational settings
2. **Decision-making** (task) - Core to signaling theory as signals help decision-makers with incomplete information
3. **Communication theory** (concept) - Examines signaling as a communication mechanism
4. **Information asymmetry** (concept) - The core problem signaling theory addresses
5. **Organizational behavior** (concept) - The primary domain where signaling theory is applied
6. **Organizational theory** (concept) - The management field context for the review

### Validation Result
✅ **PASSED** - All triples validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper entity classifications.

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all entities properly documented with their Wikipedia references and relevance statements.

Sources:
- [Signalling theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_theory)
- [Decision-making](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making)
- [Communication theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_theory)
- [Information asymmetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry)
- [Organizational behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior)
- [Organizational theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_theory)
